oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Costain, Harold
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This is a black and white photograph of the Scarsdale Supply Company on the corner of Garth and Freightway in Scarsdale, N.Y. One of the first businesses in Scarsdale, the Scarsdale Supply Company sold coal, wood, millwork, and construction materials. The entire staff (plus a few good workhorses) lined up for this photograph in 1927.

Wayside Cottage is thought to date back to 1712, making it the oldest structure in Scarsdale.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Quaker school in Scarsdale, N.Y.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This is a sepia photograph of the Quaker school. The first schoolhouse in Scarsdale School District No. 2, it was built by the Quakers circa 1815 on the corner of Weaver Street and Quaker Ridge Road. Later this building was transferred to the School District. Students sit and stand outside the small structure. The black children and white children appear to be segregated from each other. A woman, presumably the teacher, stands in the doorway.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lutheran Church of the Redeemer
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This is a color photograph of the Lutheran Church of the Redeemer that was located at 2 Murray Hill Road in Scarsdale, N.Y. It is now the Baek Min Presbyterian Church. A sign near the camera announces Sunday Service and School times. The church is red brick. A steeple with a cross on top rises over the front doors. The doors are white with a semicircular window above them, forming an arch shape.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: St. James the Less Church
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This is a photograph of a drawing of St. James the Less Church. The drawing was done in 1894 by William Bailey Lang. A stone church sits amidst a rural country setting. Three people are visible walking or working around the church. A tower is visible in the distance on the left, and part of a house in the distance on the right.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Scarsdale Community Baptist Church
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This is a color photograph of the Community Baptist Church at 51 Popham Road in Scarsdale, N.Y. The church is a stone building with a slate roof. Steps lead up to the wooden main doors. There is a cross at the apex of the roof at the front. The steeple is green and is in the middle of the roof. A lamppost stands in front of the church and there is a fire hydrant on the sidewalk. There is a brick apartment building in the background.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This is a color photograph of the Church of the Immaculate Heart of Mary, taken from the White Plains Post Road. The Immaculate Heart of Mary was founded in 1912. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Trinity Lutheran Church
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This is a photograph of the Trinity Lutheran Church at 25 Crane Road in Scarsdale, N.Y. This was formerly the Crane Family House, for which Crane Road is named. The building is a stone mansion in the Italian villa style. It has gable and mansard roofs, bracketed cornices, pedimented dormers, and a tower. There is a parking lot with cars in it. A flagpole flies the American Flag from a grassy area off the parking lot. A large cross stands atop the highest part of the church.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Scarsdale Congregational Church
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This is a black and white photograph of the Little Stone Church, constructed in 1904. This was the original structure build to house the Scarsdale Congregational Church. The building is made of irregular stones with a steep tile roof. A short path leads from the road the main entrance. The church is surrounded by bushes and grass. The land slopes down behind the church. The words “SCARSDALE CONGREGATIONAL CHURCH” are printed at the bottom of the image.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Old Quaker Meeting Houses
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This is a sepia photograph of the old Quaker Meeting Houses which were located on Weaver Street near Griffen Avenue. The original structure was constructed in 1768. In 1827 a rupture within the Quakers led to the construction of a second Meeting House on the same property at that time. The top of a stone wall is visible at the bottom of the image. There is a cottage with white siding on the left. Another similar cottage is partially visible on the right. There is another indistinguishable building in the background.
